We read in chapter 13 and verse number four how that he came to the place which he had made there at the first and there that altar that he made. Remember in verse number three, it says that he came to a place where his tent had been at the beginning between Bethel and Ai. And we find that there he had built that altar. And here the Bible says in verse number four that Abram called on the name of the Lord. He did that back in chapter number 12 as we found record of that in verse number eight. And now we see in chapter number 13 and verse number four and in verse number 18, there he built an altar unto the Lord. He's worshiping the Lord. See, Abram is living during the era of Israel's history where there is no tabernacle. That's not gonna come for a long period of time. There is no temple that's even further out in the distance. And so what did Abram do? Built an altar. By the way, that's what Noah did after he got off the ark. We spoke about that this morning as well. that he built an altar and he called upon the Lord and he's worshiping the Lord. So we think about the promises of God and we think about the way in which God is giving and speaking to Abram here in this passage of Scripture in verses 14 through 17. The natural response is to worship the Lord. To worship Him. This evening as we would take the passage of Scripture that is before us and we would consider the walk and the wisdom and the worship of Abram, I wonder as we walk with God, are we daily walking with Him like we should be? Are we in the place where we're supposed to be? Are we asking God and depending on God for the wisdom that we need for the the problems that we face in life? There will be problems. There are problems. Right? We need God's wisdom and we see that Abram, we notice his wisdom on display here in the passage. But how thankful I am for how the Lord spoke to him. You understand that God didn't speak to Lot in this fashion, in this manner. See, Lot chose something based upon sight. He lifted up his eyes and he saw this and he... By the way, he's pitched towards Sodom. We said already that the men of that city were wicked and sinners before the Lord exceedingly. He'd soon be influenced by them. But as Abram made that decision, he made that proposal and he told Lot, you choose and I'll go the other way. And then the Lord spoke to him. He says, look at every direction. I'm going to give you this land. I'm going to bless your seed. And what does he do? He worships. Can I tell you this morning? Oh man, this evening? Can I tell you tonight? Listen, three times. Man, alive. Can I tell you this evening? That we need to worship God. Listen, when you approach the Word of God and He speaks to you and He gives you some promises, oh would you just worship Him? You know, what a joy it is to just get in His presence for a little while. Not necessarily to ask for anything. Just to worship Him. Just to praise Him for who He is. Just to thank Him for giving you a Bible. For giving you a church where you can go and hear the Word of God. For giving you an opportunity to receive the promises of God. To be in a place where you've been aware of who He is. How He's revealed Himself to you. Oh, you just get in His presence a little while and you begin to just get filled with God and stand in awe of who He is. You begin to worship. It's amazing how you find yourself in that place and how God will bless. And how God will come and commune with you. And how He will meet the needs of each of us, His people. He's a God who is able. This evening we see that Abram, the passage finishes with him worshiping. With him worshiping the Lord. Building an altar. We see his walk. We see his wisdom. We see his worship. This evening, oh that we'd walk with God. Oh that we'd ask God, recognize that we need His wisdom. Get into the book and worship Him. He is worthy of our worship. Let's pray. Father, we love you. We thank you so much for loving us. We thank you for who you are. You are the Lord God Omnipotent. El Shaddai, the Lord God Almighty. In just a little while, in Bible history, from the place where we are this evening, you will reveal yourself to Abraham as El Shaddai, Lord God Almighty. We thank you that you've given us your Word. And then on a regular basis, as often as we please, we can enter into your presence. Dig into your Word. Commune with you. The thought of that calls us to rejoice. That we could be in your presence. We thank you that you spoke to Abraham. We thank you this evening that we have the entirety of the Bible and that you still speak to us today. And God, I pray that you'd help us to listen for your voice. I pray that you'd help us to enter our daily time with you in each church service that we attend. Anticipate and expecting that you're going to speak to us. Help us to receive and claim the promises. Help us, Lord, to worship you, for you are worthy of our worship. Lord, I pray this evening that we've been challenged and encouraged by the opportunity to study these events in the life of Abraham. Perhaps there are some this evening that have some problems that they're facing in life. They need your wisdom. God, would you help us, as Solomon did, to humble ourselves. To recognize that you are the all-wise God and that you've promised to give us wisdom if we simply ask. Help us to humble ourselves and to acknowledge our need. And God, we trust you to give us the wisdom that we need to navigate this life and to address problems that will arise. I pray, God, that you would work in hearts and lives that decisions would be made that would please thee and we'll thank you for it. Would you stand with me? Heads are bowed, eyes are closed. Holly's going to play quietly on the piano. As she does, we'll have a time of invitation, opportunity for you to respond. Maybe you just want to thank God. Maybe you want to ask him for wisdom. Maybe there's some problems you're dealing with in life. And you just want to come and worship the Lord a little bit this evening. Thank him for speaking to you. Thank him for allowing you to enter into his presence. As Holly plays, the altar is open.
